org.apache.freemarker.core

Interface CallPlace

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    NonTemplateCallPlace

    public interface CallPlace
    The place (in a template, usually) from where a directive (like a macro) or function was called; Do not implement this interface yourself, as new methods may be added any time! Only FreeMarker itself should provide implementations. In case you have to call something from outside a template, use NonTemplateCallPlace.INSTANCE.

    • Method Detail

      • hasNestedContent

        boolean hasNestedContent()
        Tells if there's a non-zero-length nested content. This is false for <@foo /> or <@foo></@foo> or for calls inside expressions (i.e., for function calls).

      • getNestedContentParameterCount

        int getNestedContentParameterCount()
        The number of nested content parameters in this call (like 2 in <@foo xs; k, v>...</@>). If you want the caller to specify a fixed number of nested content parameters, then this is not interesting for you, and just pass an array of that length to executeNestedContent(TemplateModel[], Writer, Environment). If, however, you want to allow the caller to declare less parameters, then this is how you know how much parameters you should calculate and pass to executeNestedContent(TemplateModel[], Writer, Environment).

      • executeNestedContent

        void executeNestedContent(TemplateModel[] nestedContentArgs,
                          Writer out,
                          Environment env)
                   throws TemplateException,
                          IOException
        Executes the nested content; it there's none, it just does nothing.
        Parameters:
        nestedContentArgs - The nested content parameter values to pass to the nested content (as in <@foo bar; i, j>${i}, ${j}</@foo> there are 2 such parameters, whose value you set here), or null if there's none. This array must be getNestedContentParameterCount() long, or else FreeMarker will throw an TemplateException with a descriptive error message that tells to user that they need to declare that many nested content parameters as the length of this array. If you want to allow the caller to not declare some of the nested content parameters, then you have to make this array shorter according to getNestedContentParameterCount().
        Throws:
        TemplateException
        IOException

      • getTemplate

        Template getTemplate()
        The template that contains this call; null if the call is not from a template (but directly from user Java code, for example).

      • getBeginColumn

        int getBeginColumn()
        The 1-based column number of the first character of the directive call in the template source code, or -1 if it's not known.

      • getBeginLine

        int getBeginLine()
        The 1-based line number of the first character of the directive call in the template source code, or -1 if it's not known.

      • getEndColumn

        int getEndColumn()
        The 1-based column number of the last character of the directive call in the template source code, or -1 if it's not known. If the directive has an end-tag (</@...>), then it points to the last character of that.

      • getEndLine

        int getEndLine()
        The 1-based line number of the last character of the directive call in the template source code, or -1 if it's not known. If the directive has an end-tag (</@...>), then it points to the last character of that.

      • getOrCreateCustomData

        Object getOrCreateCustomData(Object providerIdentity,
                             CommonSupplier<?> supplier)
                      throws CallPlaceCustomDataInitializationException
        Returns the custom data, or if that's null, then it creates and stores it in an atomic operation then returns it. This method is thread-safe, however, it doesn't ensure thread safe (like synchronized) access to the custom data itself. Be sure that the custom data only depends on things that get their final value during template parsing, not on runtime settings.

        This method will block other calls while the supplier is executing, thus, the object will be usually created only once, even if multiple threads request the value when it's still null. It doesn't stand though when providerIdentity mismatches occur (see later). Furthermore, then it's also possible that multiple objects created by the same CommonSupplier will be in use on the same time, because of directive executions already running in parallel, and because of memory synchronization delays (hardware dependent) between the threads.

        Parameters:
        providerIdentity - This is usually the class of the TemplateDirectiveModel that creates (and uses) the custom data, or if you are using your own class for the custom data object (as opposed to a class from some more generic API), then that class. This is needed as the same call place might calls different directives depending on runtime conditions, and so it must be ensured that these directives won't accidentally read each other's custom data, ending up with class cast exceptions or worse. In the current implementation, if there's a providerIdentity mismatch (means, the providerIdentity object used when the custom data was last set isn't the exactly same object as the one provided with the parameter now), the previous custom data will be just ignored as if it was null. So if multiple directives that use the custom data feature use the same call place, the caching of the custom data can be inefficient, as they will keep overwriting each other's custom data. (In a more generic implementation the providerIdentity would be a key in a IdentityHashMap, but then this feature would be slower, while providerIdentity mismatches aren't occurring in most applications.)
        supplier - Called when the custom data wasn't yet set, to invoke its initial value. If this parameter is null and the custom data wasn't set yet, then null will be returned. The returned value of CommonSupplier.get() can be any kind of object, but can't be null.
        Returns:
        The current custom data object, or possibly null if there was no CommonSupplier provided.
        Throws:
        CallPlaceCustomDataInitializationException - If the CommonSupplier had to be invoked but failed.
        UnsupportedOperationException - If this call place doesn't support storing custom date; see isCustomDataSupported().

      • isCustomDataSupported

        boolean isCustomDataSupported()
        Tells if this call place supports storing custom data. As of this writing, only top-level (i.e., outside expression) directive calls do.

      • isNestedOutputCacheable

        boolean isNestedOutputCacheable()
        Tells if the output of the nested content can be safely cached, as it only depends on the template content (not on variable values and such) and has no side-effects (other than writing to the output). Examples of cases that give false: <@foo>Name: ${name}, <@foo>Name: <#if condition>bar</#if></@foo>. Examples of cases that give true: <@foo>Name: Joe</@foo>, <@foo />. Note that we get true for no nested content, because that's equivalent to 0-length nested content.

        This method returns a pessimistic result. For example, if it sees a custom directive call, it can't know what it does, so it will assume that it's not cacheable.

      • getFirstTargetJavaParameterTypeIndex

        int getFirstTargetJavaParameterTypeIndex()
        The index of the first item in the argument array passed to execute that has this information. Used solely for speed optimization (to minimize the number of getTargetJavaParameterType(int) calls).
        Returns:
        -1 if no parameter has type hint

      • getTargetJavaParameterType

        Class<?> getTargetJavaParameterType(int argIndex)
        The type of the parameter in the target Java method; used for overloaded Java method selection. This optional information is specified by the template author in the source code (the syntax is not yet decided when I write this).
        Parameters:
        argIndex - The index of the argument in the argument array
        Returns:
        The desired Java type or null if this information wasn't specified in the template.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - Might be thrown if argIndex is an invalid index according the number of arguments on the call site. Some implementations may just return null in that case though.
